Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Experimental Investigation For the Characterization of the Geophysical Response of Rock-Fluid Interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a time when our nation must think strategically, and globally, about how to use the resources of our planet. An important task is to predict the changes that this use will cause, so we can act wisely while flourishing as a community. The mechanical and chemical interactions of fluids throughout the earth's crust are believed to drive many geological and anthropogenic processes, the ramifications of which raise major societal concerns, from contaminating ground and surface water to triggering seismic activity and deformation. Time-lapse monitoring with seismic methods is an effective approach to recognize such variations in physical properties in the ground. However, quantitative interpretation of such data is not reliable for predicting changes that result from complex, dynamic interactions of thermal, chemical, and mechanical processes due to lack of fundamental laboratory data. Current models for the seismic response to pore fluid changes stem from a purely mechanical approach, which is inadequate for predicting the effects of coupled physical and chemical alterations. This is a challenging problem, because of its complexity and multi-disciplinary nature. A major shift is required in the way experiments are conceived so to dynamically track changes both in the rock and the fluid, and how they feedback upon each other. To succeed students also need to be trained across multi-disciplines as well as the design and operation of laboratory instruments-this task can be a mission by itself. Experimental investigation is an indispensable element of scientific inquiry and must play a central role in the way current and future generations of scientist make decisions. The objective of this project is thus twofold. It leverages research by integrating innovative experiments that simulate earth conditions and chemo-mechanical processes with a combination of measurements and computations on 3D printed models of CT-scanned rocks. The project also aims to broaden education opportunities through the creation of an online laboratory that can facilitate the process of learning experimental techniques and adapt its content to the high-tech student's lifestyle. The virtual laboratory reproduces in form and function the PI research laboratory at Stanford University through interactive, 3-D animated renderings of instruments used in a geophysics laboratory that students can virtually assemble and operate. The objective is to build the necessary infrastructure allowing students to appreciate more easily the dual functions of laboratory systems: learning what these systems do and how they work, and actually using them for future research endeavors. The project will provide fertile ground for a series of new technologies and cyber capabilities both in classes and research and help turn the complexity of laboratory work into dexterity, engagement, and expanded learning opportunities to anyone, anywhere. The overall goal is to make it possible to teach introductory laboratory classes in geoscience facilities lacking research laboratories and raise awareness of professional practices among early-stage or inexperienced students so that they can hit the ground running and efficiently take on the challenge of becoming future geoscientists.

Whether the goal is fluid disposal or storage, the thermal and chemical stimulation of reservoirs, or healing or weakening processes across geothermal and seismogenic areas, real-time geophysical monitoring is emerging as a way to rapidly control processes at depth and turn data observations into decisions. The proposed research aims to improve our fundamental understanding of how to decipher changes in the earth's crust due to fluid movement and rock-fluid interactions using remote geophysical monitoring methods. Currently, quantitative interpretation of 4-D seismic data is not successful for predicting the behavior of dynamic systems underlying thermo-chemo-mechanical processes, because we lack fundamental laboratory data. Conventional laboratory experiments as well as models for seismic signatures of pore fluid changes stem from a purely mechanical approach, which is inadequate for predicting the effects of reactive transport fluids on the microstructural properties of the rock skeleton-the pore space of the rock deforms chemo-mechanically while the fluid reacts and flows through a deforming pore space. The innovative aspect of this proposal is to interlace the rock elastic properties with deformation and reactive transport flow through basic-science experimentation and multi-scale imaging. The proposed research will use laboratory experiments and time-lapse, multi-scale imaging to track both geochemical (fluid chemistry and flow, mass balance, pH) and physical parameters (transport and elastic properties, pressure buildup, dissolution-driven strain) in rocks during chemo-mechanical processes. This research will advance our knowledge by (a) measuring chemical and physical quantities continuously and simultaneously to truly couple cause and effect in the time domain and (b) complementing the experimental measurements with time-lapse, multi-scale imaging techniques to correlate the trends in the geophysical observables with the spatial changes occurring in the rock. The education component of the project leverages a current PI project to create a virtual laboratory through interactive, 3-D animated renderings of rock-physics instruments for the geophysics community. Complementing time-consuming high-pressure/high-temperature experiments and time-lapse imaging with the 3D printing of actual rock models is a way to open research to innovative tools, and possibly, to new learning perspectives through the skills of the high-tech students of this nation and abroad.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The mechanical and chemical interactions of fluids with earth materials drive many geological as well as engineered processes. This project dealt with understanding the geophysical response of rocks and geomaterials to chemical reactions under stress. This NSF CAREER grant helped develop a rock physics research program that is at the forefront in performing laboratory experiments that simulate chemical processes of the Earth subsurface under pressure and temperature (P-T) conditions. Specifically, it allowed building a research laboratory capable of (a) performing time-lapse experiments that measure the properties of the rock and fluid upon reactions under stress, (b) imaging microstructural changes across different scales of observations, and (c) supporting teaching with novel and creative use of technology and digital learning tools so students could appreciate more than ever the complexity of experimental methods. 

Research component: My advisees and I used a variety of experimental and multi-scale imaging techniques to examine how pore scale physics and chemistry affect macroscopic changes in elastic, transport, and mechanical properties. These goals required adopting a three-pronged approach so as to best represent the nature of Earth?s conditions, allow for hypothesis testing while minimizing the disadvantages that arise from rock heterogeneity, and image quasi-real-time processes from the micro-to-macro scale.

First, my laboratory built High-Temperature High-Pressure reactor-vessels and my group and I are continually involved in implementing new procedures to instrument the vessel so as to induce Earth processes under P-T conditions as high as 50 MPa and 500? C, analyze fluid chemistry composition and pH, and monitor the variation of reaction-induced rock properties. This work has proven central in studying how materials function under chemically and thermally severe environments, which is a challenge as much for geophysics as it is for materials science. For examples, I started a unique research program that studies the cementation of volcanic seals and, specifically, the reactions of volcanic ash with fluids present in hydrothermal systems of calderas (i.e., lime, alkalis, and sulfur), which have been also used to produce ancient and modern cementitious binders, including Roman concrete. The uniqueness of the program lies in having cross-pollinated knowledge across the Geosciences, Engineering, and Archaeology, spawning future research opportunities in engineering processes that manipulate geology to produce functional materials --an approach called geomimicry.

Second, I have been creative in addressing the issue of the repeatability of the response of a rock to a process imposed in the laboratory, being usually challenged by rock heterogeneity. I thus pioneered the use of 3D printing to couple the fabrication of porous rocks from CT-scan imaging with iterative, digital manipulations of pore micro-geometry. Specifically, we used 3D printing as a space machine across scales of observations so as to digitally manipulate and quantify iterative changes in pore properties (e.g., surface area and tortuosity) and then macroscopically measure the permeability on printed samples.

 Third, we benefitted from an unprecedented combination of spatial and temporal resolution to overcome the cook-and-look approach when imaging rocks in time-lapse and capture transient rock behaviors under stress. We combined dynamic (close to real-time) Ct-scan imaging of samples with simulation to study how grain chemical heterogeneities affect the evolution of porosity and permeability and start linking macroscale properties to pore scale properties.

Educational component: To foster laboratory instruction and overcome the learning challenges typical of these classes (i.e., limited time for training and availability of experimental systems), I created a first-ever virtual rock physics laboratory reproducing in form and function my laboratory at Stanford. The virtual laboratory includes online video-tutorials showing experiments through 3-D renderings of equipment as well as interactive modules for assembling instruments from a set of virtual components. My goal is to help students gain independence in designing and controlling all the steps of experimental methods as well as open up a Stanford laboratory to promising students worldwide who are currently left out of such educational resource.

Overall, this CAREER Award funded students, post-doctoral associates, and research yielding 16 publications (plus 2 publications pending)  in peer-reviewed journals such as Geophysics, Journal of Geophysical Research, Geophysical Research Letters, Construction and Building Materials, and Science.
